title: 111_hr5587
content: The United States Commission on Planetary Defense is established in the legislative branch for the purpose of addressing planetary defense issues. The Commission aims to assess the capabilities of various entities to detect and neutralize Near Earth Objects (NEOs), evaluate US Government roles in this area, determine US effectiveness in leading international efforts, and enhance NEO characterization and mitigation capabilities. The Commission aims to identify technology development needed for effective planetary defense from dangerous NEOs and report findings, conclusions, and recommendations to the President and Congress for corrective measures. SEC. 3. COMPOSITION OF COMMISSION. The Commission shall consist of 7 members appointed by various committees from the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Commission consists of 7 members appointed by committees from the House of Representatives and the Senate. Members must have expertise in various disciplines and be appointed by specific committee members. Appointees can be government officials or prominent US citizens. All members must be appointed by a specified deadline in 2010. The Commission, consisting of 7 members appointed by House and Senate committees, must be appointed by [_____, 2010]. After the initial meeting, the Commission will meet as needed with a quorum of four members. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission, consisting of 7 members appointed by House and Senate committees, must be appointed by [_____, 2010]. After the initial meeting, the Commission will meet as needed with a quorum of four members. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 4. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission's functions include evaluating government and international bodies' response to dangerous NEOs, assessing technology readiness for planetary defense, and submitting required reports to the President and Congress. The Commission's functions include evaluating government and international bodies' response to dangerous NEOs, assessing technology readiness for planetary defense, and submitting required reports to the President and Congress, which may propose organization, coordination, planning, and management arrangements. The Commission has powers to evaluate responses to dangerous NEOs, assess technology readiness for planetary defense, and submit reports to the President and Congress. The Commission, or its subcommittees, can hold hearings, gather evidence, and administer oaths. It can also enter into contracts to fulfill its duties and obtain information from federal agencies for the purposes of the Act. The Commission can request information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics from various government entities as authorized by law. Information must be handled and disseminated in accordance with relevant laws and regulations. Federal agencies can provide assistance as needed. The General Services Administration provides administrative support to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. Other departments and agencies can also offer services, funds, facilities, staff, and support as authorized by law. The Commission can accept gifts, use postal services like other government agencies, and request information from various entities. SEC. 6. NONAPPLICABILITY OF FEDERAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE ACT. The Commission is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. It will hold public meetings, release public reports, and conduct hearings while protecting sensitive information. SEC. 7. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The chairman, with the vice chairman's consultation, can appoint and set the compensation for a staff director and other necessary personnel without following certain regulations. The staff are considered federal employees. The Commission's personnel, including the executive director, are considered federal employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission is authorized to procure consultant services as needed. The Commission can procure consultant services from experts and consultants at rates not exceeding those of a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 8. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may receive compensation not exceeding the daily rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing duties for the Commission. SEC. 9. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. SEC. 9. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. The Federal agencies will provide security clearances to Commission members and staff as needed, following existing procedures. Access to classified information requires appropriate security clearances. SEC. 10. REPORTS OF COMMISSION; TERMINATION. The Commission can submit interim and final reports to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will terminate 120 days after submitting the final report. The Commission will conclude its activities by providing testimony to Congress and disseminating the final report. SEC. 11. FUNDING. $2,000,000 available for transfer to the Commission for its activities until its termination.
